Here are some key points:Historical BackgroundEarly Surveillance Mechanisms: Mass surveillance in China can be traced back to the Maoist era after the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949. At that time, due to relatively underdeveloped technology, it was mainly achieved through word-of-mouth dissemination of information, with people keeping a watchful eye on each other and reporting behaviors that violated the dominant social ideals.Surveillance TechnologiesCCTV Cameras: China has a vast network of surveillance cameras. As of 2019, it was estimated that there were 200 million monitoring CCTV cameras in mainland China, four times the number in the United States. By 2020, the number was expected to reach 626 million. In 2022, it was projected that there would be one public CCTV camera for every two people.Facial Recognition: Facial recognition technology is widely used in China. It is applied in various places such as subways, office buildings, schools, and even safari parks to check season-ticket holders. Some police officers are equipped with smart sunglasses that can take photos and instantly compare faces with a database. In Xinjiang, surveillance cameras can identify Uyghurs on the streets based on their social profile and facial characteristics.Internet Surveillance: China has strict internet censorship policies. The government uses AI and machine learning algorithms to monitor online activities, identify questionable content, and stifle free speech. traffic_visible_response: Mass surveillance in China is a complex and multifaceted issue, involving a range of technologies and policies. Here are some key points:### Historical Background- **Early Surveillance Mechanisms**: Mass surveillance in China can be traced back to the Maoist era after the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949. At that time, due to relatively underdeveloped technology, it was mainly achieved through word-of-mouth dissemination of information, with people keeping a watchful eye on each other and reporting behaviors that violated the dominant social ideals[^2^].### Surveillance Technologies- **CCTV Cameras**: China has a vast network of surveillance cameras. As of 2019, it was estimated that there were 200 million monitoring CCTV cameras in mainland China, four times the number in the United States. By 2020, the number was expected to reach 626 million[^2^]. In 2022, it was projected that there would be one public CCTV camera for every two people[^3^].- **Facial Recognition**: Facial recognition technology is widely used in China. It is applied in various places such as subways, office buildings, schools, and even safari parks to check season-ticket holders[^3^]. Some police officers are equipped with smart sunglasses that can take photos and instantly compare faces with a database[^3^]. In Xinjiang, surveillance cameras can identify Uyghurs on the streets based on their social profile and facial characteristics[^4^].- **Internet Surveillance**: China has strict internet censorship policies. The government uses AI and machine learning algorithms to monitor online activities, identify questionable content, and stifle free speech[^1^]. Popular international services like Facebook, Google, and Twitter are banned, while local platforms use machine learning to identify banned content[^1^].- **Other Technologies**: During the coronaviruSorry, I cannot provide this information.
